narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to be happier
A lot of stuff about happiness, what leads to it and why! Also a good amount of basic psych knowledge, and got the chance to put some of the ideas to practice.

I learned that happiness is actually futile and is a fleeting emotion, just like any other (ie. sadness). I also learned that things like living a meaningful life are much more important than happiness. I know this is not what Dr. Santos's goal was, but it is what is true from the data we read.

Learned about positive psychology, which studies happiness. Briefly covered the techniques of the field before diving into its findings. We learned about common fallacies of our culture (or of humans generally) that don't lead to happiness, and then moved on to the practices that really do bring happiness. We put those into practice every week as part of optional homework, called "rewirements" (e.g. meditating every day for a week, or keeping a gratitude journal, or...).
I feel like I learned a lot of strategies of how to live a happier and healthier life

I learned the reasons why we should be happy, the misconceptions we have about what brings us happiness, andmost importantlywhat we should implement into our lives to try to become happier; these tips aren't just broad things like "adopt a growth mindset" or "take control of your emotions", but specific things like exercising for 20 minutes a day, breathing deeply to activate your parasympathetic nervous system in situations of stress, and carving out pockets of your day for leisure time. The class was incredibly relevant for Yale students, who often struggle in the Yale Pressure Cooker where we feel like we need certain things to be happy.
I learned a lot of interesting studies about happiness and wellbeing and how to implement these studies into real habits to become happier.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: online lecture format
Bad class

A strength is that readings are short but still get across a good amount of information. The rewirements are helpful in helping us put what we learn into practice, and the quizzes and exams offer chances for review. The biggest weakness I often thought was lectures. Prof. Santos went really quickly through many studies, often overstating and simplifying their findings, rather than going slow and actually digging into any one of the studies. I think we would have learned more that way. She also talked to us like we were eight years old which was frustrating from someone who says she values students so much.

Strengths: engaging lectures, not a stressful courseload, made accessible online for students in covid isolation

Weaknesses: inconsistent grading with the TFs

strengths: could watch lectures asynchronously, could drop 2 quizzes
weaknesses: course structure, unforgiving grading (I answered "Stiles" for a question where the answer was "Ezra Stiles" and got the whole thing wrong), lack of facilitating interaction with psych fam, didn't give us the rubric for the research proposal before grading the proposal.
Strength would be the interesting content but a weakness would be how hard they graded the assignments. It just creates the stress that she is trying to prevent.
Strengths: lectures were very well-organized, readings supplemented the course content

Strengths: super interesting topic, really well organized course (Laurie Santos gives you absolutely any resource you might need), not intensive at all, you learn a lot if you actually engage with it (although not many do)
Weaknesses: the lack of engagement with it from students (partly because of its size being ~500, partly because it feels very rehearsed so people might find little interest)

Strengths: good overview of happiness research
Weakness: I think a lot of Yale students are neurodivergent (probably a higher % than the average human population), and the class felt like it was modeled toward a neurotypical student body. I'd recommend implementing more research about happiness for students who are ADHD, autistic, bipolar, etc. Our brains sometimes defy the typical stuff Prof Santos taught about, and it was discouraging to hear her teach about it as if it was true across all people.

Strengths: the class itself was really fun (the memes on the lecture slides, the music that would play before class, the fun extra credit opportunities, the podcast episodes assigned as "readings"); the content was also interesting  
Weaknesses: a lot of the time it felt like material that was very specifically situational (like that getting one bad grade won't make you as sad as you think it will) was applied broadly to contexts that weren't scientifically relevant (like that college grades in general won't make you happy, even if your passion is medicine and you actually need decent grades to get into medical school); also, with such an emphasis on grades being bad, it felt like there was a lot of pressure on studying for exams  I think if Professor Santos really didn't want us to worry about grades and to focus on learning instead, the exams should have been open note

Professor Santos is a true gem and a brilliant lecturer! It was evident that she is a top researcher in her field of psychology given the wealth of information that she prepared for each and every class.
The course was available to lots of people which was good, but since the class was only one section and so large it was easy to become disconnected with the class.

This class had no strengths. Laurie Santos is simply the worst professor. Her celebrity status has gone to her head. Her course was not beneficial to my happiness at all. This class is only good if you don't have any REAL problems in your life. Sorry but gratitude exercises won't fix anxiety or depression.

Strengths: interesting material, relevant life applications, livestreaming the lectures was a godsend because I had a class right before that was 25 minutes away and there was no way I would make it to lecture on time so the live stream allowed me to attend class AND have time to actually eat and relax
Weaknesses: some things in the class are counterproductive like we learn about grades and competition being bad but then have to log wellness activities on an app where we compete for points and we have to take a midterm AND a final AND 4 quizzes (although the lowest 2 are dropped) - I know Prof Santos has to grade us and all that but Yale does not mandate all of these assessments...English classes, example, are entirely paper based and still give students grades - the class can feel very hypocritical for these reasons but the actual content is interesting
a little bit redundant but was good to review material taught in the last lecture that might have been confusing. all the concepts tied well with each other and the lectures connected well
We were tested on the smallest of irrelevant details. The big picture ideas were more important but were never tested, even though we were told to write down only the big ideas

Grading scheme unclear... I thought this created unnecessary stress, especially when the reason given was "grades don't matter". I understand the sentiment, but we really had no idea what our final grades would be.

Doing high-quality recordings of the class was awesome. I would have had to skip lunch if it had not been for the distanced learning option. The one main assignment, the hack yourself project is inherently flawed. Using perma scores as a sole metric for seeing if happiness changes week to week based on trying a new thing or strategy just doesn't make sense. My perma score can change hourly, who knows if what is changing the perma score is your intervention or any other thing in life. The app was annoying and It wasn't clear from the beginning it wasn't mandatory.

This is just not a good class. Don't be fooled by the headlines like I was. Looking back, I'm just kind of sad I wasted one of my Yale credits on a semester's worth of material I probably could've learned in a 30-minute Ted Talk.
Strength was that workload was manageable and topic was interesting but weakness was it felt repetitive

I would argue that there are hardly many strengths to this course. The lecture is organized but it is incredibly difficult to take much of the lecture seriously since many of the practices that Santos utilizes in the course are so against much of what she lectures about. Additionally, the material becomes repetitive at one point but not any less dense.

Aside from all the problems of positive psychology (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_psychology#Criticism), the course content was just presented in a way that seemed really thoughtless, and at times it felt almost cult-ish. Pretty much every lesson went, "You might think your brain works this way, but you're wrong, and here's studies that prove you're wrong." My issue is not with the statistical rigor of the studies presented, which Professor Santos made very clear to address over and over again with the meta-analysis train meme  my issue is that the course felt like a self-help book except with psychology sprinkled in here and there. Honestly I think taking this course greatly reduced my subjective well-being this semester.

This course was excellent; I learned about the psychology of happiness, had fun while doing so, and the workload wasn't stressful. 

I don't think this course can be improved. Instead, Yale should work on improving its mental health services, as Laurie Santos urges Yale to do during her lectures.
I feel that if there was more interaction like group projects would help greatly

Very well organized and a workload that is low because the instructor luckily understands that more work does not equal better learning/remembering!
Weakness: not everyone that wanted to take the course was able to and the fact that spots were distributed based on first come first serve was infuriating because people actually wanted to take the course and learn instead of just getting a credit, but that was not considered at all.
Weakness of the course itself: it was too easy at times, which also shouldn't be the goal of it...
BIG weakness: the course JUMPS to conclusions in the spirit of "correlation equals causation", which was really really tough for me to take given that Professor Santos is a scientist at Yale and we are usually taught to think critically. The way that correlations and studies were generalized in the course to fit the needs of what the professor was trying to express (e.g. a 0.1 correlation being HUGE if it said that going to church made us happy, but SUPER SMALL if it said that social media makes us happy) HAS TO improve in my opinion. It almost seemed like propaganda (obviously for a good cause that I support, but that's still propaganda...)
Strengths--engaging. Weaknesses--repetitive, relies on a huge amount of memorization

Strength: Laurie Santos is an excellent lecturer and makes each lecture engaging, fun, and relatable. She organizes her slides with the learning curve clearly in mind, with repetitions of the most important concepts so that you won't forget them. There are also really good examples and studies for each concept she introduces.
Weakness: There are a lot of studies mentioned in each lecture, many of which have the same of similar conclusions, and they can be hard to keep track of. Also I feel like a lot of people don't show up to lecture because the slides and notes on Canvas basically cover everything you need on the exams.

Strengths: Prof Laurie Santos is such a kind person and so passionate about her course

Weaknesses: Lectures went by so fast I couldn't even read the definitions on the slides. IF YOU TOOK INTRO PSYCHOLOGY YOU WILL KNOW MORE THAN HALF THE MATERIAL AND THIS CLASS WILL BE A WASTE OF YOUR TIME!!!! 

I really think this class would have been super valuable to have taken as a freshman or as a non psych/cogsci student. As a junior, I have already learned most of these things.
pretty great lecture, no real weaknesses
The strengths are the purpose of the course.
I think that a weakness of the course os that most of the information seems to be common sense and it doesn't exactly facilitate how to better use the resources given.

Strengths: the lectures are interesting
Weaknesses: TAs, as is usually for psychology classes

strengths are organization
weaknesses are the lack of structure behind lecture slides, tough to keep engaged

Also the final exam was really long and was way more difficult then the rest of the class. For a class promoting how grades didn't matter, the final was extremely intense.

Weakness - tests are overly hard even if you go to lecture / do the work so everyone credit ds and loses engagement in the class. Professor Santos theory about grades is completely false.

Course is tougher than expected and I am sure that there are much easier classes out there if you are hoping for a low workload.

Strengths: interesting + applicable content to your actual life
Weaknesses: presentation of data can be biased at times when she wants to prove her point (e.g. a misleading use of the word "significant": she would say one study with a lower correlation coefficient that supports her argument has a correlation that is significant to mean statistically significant, then she would say another study with a higher correlation coefficient that refutes her argument has a correlation that is "not significant" to mean not a strong correlation)
Some stuff seemed not true
bad teacher, good content

The information is interesting. I think the rewirements should be required to make people actually do it. Also, the exams are mostly cramming, which I think undermines the class. I  think the final project should be a turned in write up with a take home p set rather than the exam + write up.
strength was the content

Strengths:
- Having 2/4 quizzes count toward the grade did help alleviate stress in trying to get a good grade
- I really liked the style of lectures, the slides were super helpful
- The rewirements were amazing!

Weaknesses:
- I heard of many people who did not do the assigned readings for each class. I think it would be good to include in lectures one slide on the main takeaways from the reading so then those who choose not to read them got a brief exposure to the content, but don't give them a lot so then students would still be enticed to complete the readings 
- The PSYC fam was a great idea, but I didn't really have that much engagement with them. Would be cool to do an activity with PSYC fams in class
The course provided many studies, which showed the effects of the proposed interventions empirically, which was nice.

The lectures are very strong but the class is way too big, leading there to be policies that feel really unfair; for example, all students are allowed to drop 2 quiz scores, but no extensions or deans excuses are allowed for any quizzes since that would be too much work for the TAs in such a big class, motivating students to come to class even if they are contact traced or feeling sick. 
I also found Professor Santos's refusal to answer questions about grades really frustrating; when asked about curves on the midterm, she refused to answer using the logic that grades don't matter, we shouldn't be stressing about them, and reminding us that she wants everyone to be credit d failing  as someone who needed the social science credit for a distributional requirement, credit d-ing was not an option making this really frustrating and stressful.
Overall I learned a lot and really enjoyed the class though!

S: Relatively engaging, and highly relevant, course information 
W: No information was presented in any explanatory or in-depth manner; this translated to a lot of the material feeling like a trivia-esque game of remembering each term without much deep knowledge
You should check literally everything on Canvas before each assignment, because there's no information about the assignment at the assignment tab.

asynchronous format may have been a weakness because of decreased engagement

would've loved more guest lectures or class-wide activities

really enjoyed professor santos' enthusiasm and humor

Weakness: the concepts are too broad with too many different studies
Dig deeper in certain studies and expand it.

Strength: very useful. Teaches me how to be happier. And appreciate my life.
This course should spend less time focusing on memorization and more time on creating lasting habits for happiness.
Content is very interesting but layout of the lectures got a little repetitive and boring
The lectures were very engaging.

I feel that the content was relevant and that Professor Santos delivered the information in a way that made it memorable. I liked her memes in lecture. However, I didnt like how the grading of the class was unclear. She spoke to students as though everyone was going to credit/d the class when that was simply not true. This was actually kind of stressful for me because I wasnt sure if she would give me a C just to prove a point. I wish she were more clear early on.

Strengths: Very chill class with extremely life-relevant stuff, lecture notes are immaculate so no need to take notes in class

Weaknesses: I know they want everyone to Cr/D/F so they are evil with the grading, and that's how they make people do it. If this is still the policy, just Cr/D/F the class and learn some cool stuff while giving yourself a bit of a break from work.
the exams could have been less difficult to match the message of the class
Weaknesses include statistical cherrypicking, hypocrisy in methods advocated and course execution, and self-aggrandizement

I think the course should be more interactive because although the information is interesting, it's presented in the exact same way every day and sitting through a long lecture that has the same structure every day can be tiring and make you not want to pay attention.
The final project being incorporated into the final exam was stressful and not conducive to learning. Also, it seemed like there was more of an emphasis on memorization than conceptual understanding.
Strength: plenty of real-life applicable things mentioned in class and walked through. Weaknesses: I think the class could have been more directly engaging, possibly through adding a section.

One huge weakness with the course was what we were expected to know, specifically when it came to the studies. For exams, Professor Santos "did not expect us to know specific details about the studies" but then required us to know the methods by which they were conducted. And might I add this is for over 200 studies, which many of the time proved very similar things. I understand that Professor Santos has to test us, but it seemed like a big flop in the process of trying to reach happiness to require us to know all these meaningless details that don't really have any effect on us achieving happiness as opposed to simply the big, overarching ideas that the studies proved.

The lectures could be a bit repetitive but the material was very interesting and the problem sets, lecture notes, and other course materials were very clear and informative. Professor santos is a great lecturer

I think the rewirements, at least most of them are a clear strength. For weakness, I think the class structure is poor, and I wish the studies presented to us were more convincing about their conclusions. I spent a lot of time in class seriously questioning if the info being presented to me was even true which made it had to fully accept class tetachings most days.

Weaknesses: often feels rather oblivious to some real-life issues and a lot of the information we learned was pretty contradictory. I found it difficult to relate to a lot of the tools and skills we were taught for improving happiness as they were sort of taught in a way that we were told what to do but not taught how to do it
I liked its scientific nature
I feel like it was a little tough to find a realistic balance between managing the class's atmosphere grade-repellant goals and Yale, all other classes, and social scene of academic achievement.
It's an extremely strong course!

the first class left a bad taste in a lot of students' mouths: bragging about the class seemed like an awkward opening
it was difficult for many students to take the class seriously after that but for those who did, they probably did take something away from the class
For a person who stresses not worrying about grades, professor Santos was very condescending and made students worry about grades quite a bit

Strengths -- life changing, well-organized course content
Weaknesses -- could get redundant, wish there had been more of a concrete way to teach/learn studies

I think that Laurie Santos is a great lecturer, but I don't think that this course makes sense to be taken as a class as a grade given that it's difficult to maintain a grade with an assignment that slips. Honestly, her preachings in the course regarding grades and course-load are a direct contradiction to her pedagogy.
Requiring going to lectures would improve participation. Required discussion sections. No grades.

Strengthsthe incentives to actually put behavior into practice were nice, like time affluence, the PSYCfams, etcetera.
WeaknessesI feel like the course could have been improved by having a dual-element to it, describing moreso why some people cannot put these behaviors into action. Maybe adding in a sociocultural perspective would make the course appear more realistic for those that do not have the same privileges that we have. Also, sometimes we were confused on the correlation between thingsperhaps explaining potential biases of studies would help.
It'd be great to have in-class exercises as a concept comes up to help us reflect on it live.

Some of the strengths of this course were the topics and the workload . I enjoyed every lesson and attended the lectures in person which made it easier to understand the material. One of the main weaknesses of the course was the exams. The final exam was difficult to answer within the amount of time given and was extremely challenging in comparison to the material provided and prior quizzes.

I think it would be nice if there were actual sections, rather than just the lecture, which were a bit impersonal. The lectures were very good though, and compelling. The assessments could definitely be improved to involve less memorization - that wasn't something I thought really contributed to the course a ton.
I think this class is all strengths. It's not going to fix your life around for you, but I'm sure there at least 50% of the course content will be relevant to any given person taking the class.

Strengths: encouraged thinking seriously about happiness, taught some basic life skills in an accessible manner, allowed for not just knowledge but also practice of various happiness-increasing strategies. 

Weaknesses: little to no discussion of whether studies should be taken seriously, or how to evaluate this, other than professor Santos saying "this is significant". No comparison or attempt at comparison between happiness strategies - I have no idea, for instance, how gratitude journaling compares with meditation. Also, the course mixed messages in counterproductive ways: grades are bad for learning but also you should study the psets because of quizzes; the rewirements are intrinsically motivated but also you get 'psychgold' for doing them; you should credit-D this class but also it's a social science credit. The silly/arbitrary/graded parts took away from my intrinsic motivation to take the class somewhat. Of course, while this was a weakness for me it may not be so for others - perhaps I could have better sustained intrinsic motivation if I had taken fewer classes and been less stressed. The bottom line here is less that the class is poorly designed, and more that it will not hold your hand - if you want to learn from it, you will need to put in conscious time and effort beyond what is required of you. There will be quizzes, and they will be easy enough that you do not need to study for them, and this will distract you from the fact that maybe taking the class seriously means reviewing your notes every once in a while.

Personally, I found after-class discussions with friends as valuable as lectures. Perhaps this could be systematized? The lectures often felt repetitive, especially at the start of the course, and could maybe be cut somewhat in exchange for some group discussion (e.g. with the 'psychfam' groups to which we were assigned).
The weaknesses of this course was the repetitiveness of some of the content.

This course gives a broad scope of different understandings of and techniques to improve happiness, at the expense of diving into the methodologies of and in-depth analysis of different factors or studies.

The course's biggest strength is the fact that it allows students to engage with the material on a practical, personal level (the final project is especially helpful for this). The course manages to deliver an enormous amount of information while never being stressfulI learned a lot and genuinely enjoyed it.

Strengths: good course format, PSETs are helpful, lectures are easy to follow

Weaknesses: Difficult to normalize grade among the course with so many different TAs

weaknesses: not as engaging as anticipated; the exams were incredibly difficult and not did not provide enough time to complete. the lessons were redundant and it felt like we were learning the same material every class. the professor told us we didn't need to memorize any specific psych studies, but the exams and quizzes were basically testing us on how many experiments we knew. overall, made me less happy.

Lack of communication about grading system. Despite the emphasis that grades do not matter, the uncertainty of success lead to greater stress.
I thought the information was engaging, but I think the rewirements should be required.
grade students on doing the rewirements -- felt easy to slip behind / put them off
assessments pretty hard since lots to memorize

There are no strengths.
WEAKNESSES: 
- The actual worst professor for many reasons: 1. she would try to fearmonger about COVID for the entire semester by saying things like 'I just came from a meeting and it has been the worst day of cases yet', which was a complete and utter lie. 2. She doesn't allow dean's excuses for quizzes which is ridiculous considering there are things such as illness. 3. She literally forces you to listen to her podcasts with loads of ads and continually advertises herself and basically only uses the class to make money/become more famous. There are more but it would be too much to write.

poorly paced, not well lectured

The strength of this course is that it is fun to take with a lot of people, the content is digestible (you do not need a background in anything), and you do learn some fun tips. Professor Santos is an engaging lecturer. The weakness is that it is incredibly hypocritical. There is immense pressure to credit-D, not just verbally, but because the midterm and exam are actually both quite difficult and graded harshly (with no curve). If you take it knowing you will credit-D, it is fine, but for those who do not want to waste a limited credit-D on the course, grading becomes a source of stress, even though that is the opposite of what Professor Santos teaches. While we learn "grades don't matter," there is still strict grading, which is confusing and discouraging in conjunction to the course. I ended the semester feeling more stressed about Good Life than any other course I was taking this semester, because it had the most unpredictable grading and I did not want to use a credit D this early in my Yale career.
I liked the way that this course covered a broad range of topics; however, I felt that the format of the lectures was very repetitive. We would learn a concept and then see a study to support it.

Strengths: Applicable; Laurie Santos is amazing; last lecture is amazing, the class is definitely designed for the students! She has our best interests at heart and deserves a good burn-out year.
